awd_titl_txt: XPS: FULL: DSD: Parallel Motion Planning for Cloud-connected Robots
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots are entering new domains, from self-driving vehicles on real-world streets, to autonomous aerial vehicles for package delivery, to assistive robots helping people with disabilities in their homes with daily activities. Autonomous robots in these domains often need extensive computational resources for motion planning, which involves computing a safe motion for a robot through an environment that avoids obstacles and accomplishes the task. To enable low-power mobile robots to achieve their full potential, new algorithms and software frameworks are needed that fully leverage parallel computation and the warehouse-scale computing available via the cloud.   This project aims to develop a new software framework for motion planning for cloud-connected robots that effectively parallelizes motion planning and distributes the computation across the robot's embedded multicore processor and multiple cloud-based compute servers. 

This research combines ideas from multiple areas of computer science and engineering, including robotics, parallel algorithms, high-performance computing, motion planning, and cloud computing. Locally on the robot, the project parallelizes traditional motion planners to fully leverage low-power, embedded multicore processors. Simultaneously, the project enables the robot to request computation time from cloud-based resources to significantly increase the computing power available for the motion planning task, and thus increase the responsiveness and quality of motion plans. The new algorithms and software aim to enable robots to autonomously complete tasks in new domains where the challenge of motion planning is currently prohibitive, broadening the applicability of robots to new societally-relevant domains. 

The concepts and software developed in this project are being integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses taught across topics ranging from robotics to high-performance computing. Another goal of the project is to create fun, hands-on, interactive demonstrations using cloud-connected robots to inspire children to consider STEM fields.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Robots are entering new domains, from self-driving cars operating on real-world streets to autonomous drones delivering packages to assistive robots helping people in their homes with daily activities. In contrast to robots in traditional industrial settings, robots performing the tasks above must move through unstructured, dynamic environments and may need to interact with people and nature. To achieve their full potential in these new domains, robots need extensive computational resources for motion planning, which involves computing a safe motion for a robot through an environment that avoids obstacles and accomplishes the task. As robots transition from isolated systems in structured environments such as factories to mobile robot systems operating in human-centric and natural environments, they will need new algorithms and software frameworks that can enable efficient computation of complex, challenging motion plans.

In this project, we developed new methods to enable robots to quickly and efficiently compute challenging motion plans by fully leveraging parallel computation and the warehouse-scale computing available via the cloud. Specifically, we developed new algorithms and a new software framework for motion planning for cloud-connected robots that effectively parallelizes motion planning and distributes the computation across the robot's embedded processor and cloud-based multi-core servers. Locally on the robot, we parallelize traditional motion planners to fully leverage low-power, embedded multicore processors while ensuring that the power constraints and real-time constraints necessary for safe robot operation are satisfied. Simultaneously, we enable the robot to request computation time from cloud-based resources to significantly increase the computing power available for the motion planning task, and thus increase the responsiveness and quality of motion plans. A key challenge is distributing the computation in an effective manner: the embedded processor has low latency but limited computation power, while the cloud-based service has higher latency but immense computational power. Our new methods account for network latencies and bandwidth constraints by appropriately partitioning the motion planning problem over time and space between the local and remote processors. 

Our new algorithms and software have the potential to enable robots to autonomously complete tasks in new domains where the challenge of motion planning is currently prohibitive. This includes tasks in challenging domains that could have significant societal benefits, including package delivery using autonomous aerial vehicles, search and rescue in remote environments using robots, and personal assistance in the home with tasks of daily living such as cooking and cleaning for people with disabilities.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2021
Modified by: Ron Alterovitz
